titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Walking this morning I met Mr Wiggers, and asked him if he still entertained the opinion that there would be no War between France and Russia— He said that opinion had applied only to the last year, and he did not entertain it now. I also called upon Mr Harris, who lent me some English Newspapers to 1. May inclusive— Mr Fisher, Mr Ingraham and Mr. J. W. Smith of Boston dined with us— After dinner I called at Count Bussche’s House in the Country to see him, but he was not at home. He called three times in the course of the day to see me, but we always missed each other— I returned Mr Harris’s papers, and met and walked on the Quay and Boulevard with him— On returning home I found the Chevalier and Madame Bezerra at our house; and Captain Guedes— I read the second Canto of the Lady of the Lake.

2. A prospective View of the political state of Affairs in Europe, and an estimate of their probable operation upon my private concerns induced me this morning to determine upon an arrangement, which required the agency of Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner, I therefore called this morning upon Mr Meyer with my papers, and left them with him— I then paid successively visits to the French Ambassador, to General Pardo, and to the Chevalier de Bray, with all of whom I had much Conversation— The Ambassador is in a state of great uncertainty as to the Event, and still professes to have hopes that the Peace between France and Russia will be preserved. He assured me with the most solemn protestation that no proposition of a derogatory nature had been made by France to the Emperor Alexander— That indeed there had been no propositions at-all— Que la Negotiation est encore Vierge.— He spoke even with some appearance of expectation that there might be a negotiation for a general Peace, and that it might prove successful— I told him I had no hopes of that with the present British Ministry— The System on both sides was wound up too high.— Whenever there should be a serious design for Peace, both France and England must yield largely of their present pretensions— England much more than France; but both a great deal— But why (said he) should not they take the basis of uti possidetis.— Let them keep the Colonies; and do what they please with Portugal, and we will keep Hanover and Spain— I did not think the present English Ministry would abandon Spain— Why not?— It would be precisely as it was before the French Revolution— France and Spain under one Family?— I did not know what another English Ministry might do, but the present one had pledged itself too much to their party in Spain, and to their own Country to retreat from that ground.— The Ambassador said the Accounts from Wilna were this day of a more pacific complexion than the last— The Emperor had sent Prince Trubezkoi, an Aide de Camp General, with a letter to the Emperor Napoleon, he supposed to Warsaw, in answer to that which had been brought by M. de Narbonne, also an Aide de Camp General to Wilna.— I mentioned the ex-king of Sweden’s journey to Vienna, precisely at this juncture, as leading to conjectures that there might be a project for restoring him— Why not? said the Count— If the present Swedish Government choose to be at War with us, why should not we support the late king; who has certainly a strong party in that Country; and especially his Son— I agreed with him that there was nothing to be said against the policy, and expressed my surprize at seeing the Swedish Government now falling into the identical political course which had hurled the late king from his throne— I asked the Ambassador to enclose a letter for me to Paris, by his next Courier; which he promised— I found General Pardo, recovering from his illness, but looking very ill— His disorder has been a nervous fever— He told me he was going to take the waters at Egra in Bohemia— That he should resign his office, and live as a private man, some where in the Austrian dominions— It was the only Country where he could reside— He did not chuse to go to France— En Espagne on ne veut pas de moi— The Climate of this Country was too severe for him— He did not like the English or their habits of Society; though he liked very well to read their writings— So that there was no part of Europe where he could live comfortably but in the Austrian Dominions.— The General’s situation is painful and distressing, and he has not energy of character adequate to the adversity which has befallen him— He told me some time ago that in case of the War, he was determined to stay here at all Events— As the crisis approaches, he sees the subject with other eyes; and on the subject of the War itself I have never heard him speak rationally untill this day.— He thinks it possible yet that the storm may blow over—though extremely improbable— Not that there would be much difficulty in finding terms for a compromise; but because both parties must yield more than they can easily reconcile to themselves; with such forces at their backs— Because they will come to the negotiation with an extreme distrust and jealousy of each other; because the Emperor Alexander, with the sentiment of his force will feel a Confidence that he had not before— Because the Emperor Napoleon, must make sacrifices for a compromise, not verbal and apparent, but great and real, to be seen and judged of by all Europe— But then he is not upon a Bed of Roses— He wants Peace, and must be ready to do much for obtaining it; and as to Russia, she has lost an immense advantage by adhering to her defensive system and not taking the line
of the Vistula— That would have forced Prussia to an Alliance with Russia— Now she was on the other side— The position of Russia was much more unfavourable— “Et puis, tant bien que mal cet homme (Napoleon) traine toute l’Europe après lui.” All this is very sensible, but totally opposed to every thing that the General has oftentimes said to me before— He said nothing of the Affairs in Spain— I found the Chevalier de Bray, in the midst of preparations for his departure— His wife, and family are gone—last Wednesday. While I was with him the Chevalier Brancia came in— Walk again in the Evening.

3. There were here this morning, several Sailors; Americans which came in the Monticello, a vessel seized and condemned for having come here last Summer, under the American flag and with false papers— They are unable to obtain payment of their wages, and have various other Complaints, which they have time after time brought to me though I could only refer them to the Consul, for the means of obtaining for them Justice or Relief— Captain Stanwood, and Mr Fisher called upon me— Captain Stanwood wishes to go to Gothenburg, and came to ask if I could procure for him a Passport— I knew not whether a Courier’s Passport could be granted by Count Soltykoff;—he is not authorized to grant others; and none can be obtained but by sending for them to Wilna.— Mr Harris called on me— He had a letter from Mr Sparrow at Cronstadt, concerning the American Sailors, and speaking of their claim, with censure, as if they were to blame in their demands.— He read me this passage of Sparrow’s letter; which displeased me; as the men claim nothing but their right; as they have been much injured men, and as I thought harshly treated, by Sparrow who as the Consular agent ought to have been their special and zealous protector. I expressed warmly my displeasure at the particular passage of Sparrow’s letter, which I thought unjust to the Seamen— Mr Harris took upon himself the whole of Sparrow’s proceedings, and became himself extremely warm— His temper provoked mine; untill I told him I thought he had always been too ready to disregard or slight the complaints of Common Sailors, and that in this instance they had repeatedly stated to me that measures were used to compel them to ship again in some of the vessels in which they came—false Americans; with false Colours and Papers—which the Captains or owners have contrived to get back; notwithstanding their seizure— That I had reason to believe other vessels than those that were seized had come here last year with false American Colours, and had been admitted— That if any of these Sailors should finally be forced to ship in those fraudulent vessels, I must make my report of it to the Government of U.S. as he would doubtless make his— That he knew how much I had been surprized at his proposal to take Marks’s Bond for the Papers of the Angerona, after I had told him I knew that Marks came with false Papers— That it was impossible for me to be ignorant of the immense trade carried on with England by his partner Mr Meyer, in which he was of course personally interested; and that it was singular that of the vessels which were admitted last Summer, which I had reason to believe were false Americans, one or more had come addressed precisely to Mr Meyer’s House— These remarks, all true, and as I believe all proper to be made, were expressed by me with too much heat of temper— Harris treated them as imputations which he utterly disdained— He asserted that he was perfectly independent of any authority of mine, and not accountable to me—(which was true) He said he was above every thing like the imputations I had cast upon him—that he scorned to answer them— That he would not suffer them from me— I told him, that on my part I disdained all Dissimulation with him— And that he might act his pleasure— He had already risen from his chair in great Anger— Our Conversation had become loud and highly irritated on both sides— He closed by saying with a very elevated look and tone “from this moment, Sir, all relations between you and me, have entirely ceased”—to which I answered with equal vehemence and anger “perfectly content, Sir”—your very humble “Servant”— He immediately left my chamber and my house— I went with the Ladies, and dined with the Chevalier and Madam Bezerra— General Betancourt, his Lady and two daughters were there. Madame Colombi, and her Sister Frederica. After dinner I had some Conversation with Mr Bezerra in his Cabinet— He had last Night received news, of the death of Count Linhares the Prince Regent of Portugal’s Minister of Foreign Affairs; his particular and most intimate friend; and by far the ablest man at the Court of Brezil— So Superior indeed to all the rest, that Mr Bezerra said he did not know what the Prince would do without him.— After dinner I called upon Count Soltykoff, to ask him if he would furnish me with a Courier’s Passport for Mr Stanwood to go to Gothenburg, which he said he would do with pleasure.
The French Ambassador came in at Count Soltykoff’s, very soon after me; which induced me to shorten my visit. I took a ride with the Ladies and Children; and walked home.— I then received a letter from Mr Harris; which I thought it best to keep untill to-morrow Morning, to answer it with due deliberation.

4. I answered this morning very briefly Mr Harris’s letter, and in the course of the day received a second from him which I also answered.— I sent likewise an answer to the letter of Complaint I had received from the crew of the Monticello— I finally settled a matter in dispute about a purchase at auction made a Month or six weeks ago, at Hémilian’s— An affair in which I was deceived; and which I now compromised.— Morning visit from Mr Montréal— He first mentioned to me the report that Mr Perceval the English Chancellor of the Exchequer had been assassinated by a pistol shot in open Parliament— I gave no credit to the report— Walked with Charles this morning; and alone after dinner—

5. Long visit this morning from Count Bussche, and Conversation with him.— I received a note from the French Ambassador informing me that he should dispatch this Evening a Courier, who would take any letters for me— I finished and closed letters to Mr Erving, and Mr Barlow, and took them myself to the Ambassadors House, and gave them to his Porter— I received a third letter from Mr Harris; which I answered at some length— Charles has been drooping several days, and this Evening was quite unwell.— I yesterday finished reading with him the first Volume of Berquin— Two of the Monticello’s Sailors were again with me this day.

6. A variety of circumstances, of little or no connection with public affairs engage my attention and waste my time in a manner not pleasant to me, but which I find unavoidable— I sent this morning the third letter, which I had yesterday written to Mr Harris, and received from him a fourth, proposing to call upon me to-morrow; which only required the answer that I shall be glad to see him— This Correspondence has now closed, Mr Harris having sufficiently apologized to me for his hasty conduct and language, and I having explained to him the occasion of the warmth of mine— In this dispute I have felt myself upon such immoveable ground as to the merits, and I had so strong provocation to the anger which I manifested that I have not thought myself required to offer to him any excuse or apology for it— I withheld even all explanation untill he had unequivocally acknowledged and suitably apologized for his own fault— I then gave him the explanation; but still without apology—because in any view of the subject I owe him none— To myself, I cannot so easily excuse, my want of Controul over my own temper— I do not recollect an expression, which I ought to recall— My wrong was in the tone, in the vehemence of manner and sharpness of voice and demeanour, a sin that too easily besets me, and which I have many years struggled ineffectually to subdue— This day another affair of a nature altogether domestic, occupied part of my time and reflections— I was asked by Mrs Adams to explain the motives of my own conduct, in relation to a subject which has become interesting to her Sister Catherine— I gave this explanation; which must lead to certain enquiries and further proceedings of which it is unnecessary for me at present to say more. I dined, with Mr Smith and Charles at Mr Raimbert’s— There was a Mr Le Brun, a French Officer in the Russian Service, and another Old Officer, who has been long in Siberia, and is going there again, present.— I asked Mr Montreal to call upon me, on Monday Morning, for some arrangement of an Affair in which Mr Smith is concerned.— From the French Newspapers which came this day, there seems little doubt but that the Story of Mr Perceval’s Assassination which I had disbelieved, was nevertheless true.

7. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and further apologized to me for his vivacities of last Wednesday— I told him I was desirous of forgetting every thing of an unpleasant Nature that had passed between us. He brought and left with me Copies of the Letters that he had written in behalf of the Sailors, and to secure the payment of their wages— While he was here I received, from Mr Speyer at Stockholm a packet, brought by Mr Richard Willing junr: for whom he had procured a Courier’s Passport, for the purpose— It enclosed one from Mr Russell at London, transmitting a Declaration of the English Regent concerning the Orders in Council, and Newspapers filled with the Correspondence relative to Mr John Henry’s secret mission in 1809 to Boston— There were also letters from my father and mother, which had been opened by the British Admiralty Court at London— These Letters and papers absorbed all the remainder of the day and Evening, and totally deprived me of all my customary reading and reflection of the day— How many times this has happened, since I have been in this Country!— After dinner I rode with the Ladies and Children to Chrestoffsky Island, and walked home, from near the house where we resided last Summer— Charles was quite unwell; which added more perhaps than it ought, to my anxieties.— My Mind has during the last week been constantly kept in a tumultuous state unfavourable to all regular occupation—

8. Visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Harris, Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham, and Mr Richard Willing— Being so late up last Night, I was of course late up this morning; and finding myself unwell, my time was wasted as to every valuable purpose— I had some explanation with Mr Montreal and Mr Harris respecting Mr Smith’s affairs— Mr Willing who sailed from Philadelphia in March, has come to take the place of Mr Blodget in the Commercial House which he had formed here.— After dinner I rode with the Ladies to Kammenoi-Ostroff, and walked home— Charles is yet quite unwell.

9. Visits from Count Bussche, and from Captain Stanwood, who concludes to go by water to Sweden, and wishes to have his Passport next Monday— Immediately after dinner I received a Note from Mr Tilden, just arrived from America, with letters, and Packets of Newspapers from Boston; and a small volume upon Comets sent me by Judge Davis— We rode on the way to Peterhoff and on returning I walked home— I was up untill past one in the morning, reading the newspapers. I am much displeased at the manner in which my time melts away, without having the resolution or perseverance, to apply the remedy— I found by the Newspapers that my brother had lost his youngest Child.— Mr Fisher, Mr Ingraham and Mr Blanchard met with an accident in coming up from Cronstadt last Evening— Their boat was overset, and they all narrowly escaped drowning—

10. Mr Montreal and Mr Tilden passed part of the morning with me, and Mr Hall and Mr E. Plummer paid us visits in the Evening.— My wife received letters from her Sisters and from my Mother.— I took a short walk before dinner, but was driven back by the Rain— After dinner I walked to the Summer Gardens— Mr Hall who sailed from Boston in February last, gave us information of the Death of Captain Beckford, with whom we came to Russia.

11. The Chevalier de Bray the Bavarian Minister called upon me this Morning to take leave. He goes to-morrow Evening, or on Saturday, for Dorpat, and the Seat of his father in Law Baron Löwenstern, where Madame de Bray now is— Count Jenison, remains as Chargé d’Affairs until the explosion— The Chevalier requested me when that happens to take charge of a small trunk, containing papers belonging to the Bavarian Legation to be kept untill the Peace, or untill called for by some person duly authorized by the Bavarian Court to receive it— The French Ambassador applied last week to Count Soltykoff last week for Passports to go to Wilna— The Count having no authority to grant them dispatched a Messenger to the Emperor with the request— The answer is expected to-morrow or the next day; and the Ambassador will go immediately afterwards.— I wrote to the Secretary of State. Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit— Mr Slade also called upon me, with a Mr Wallis, just arrived from Gothenburg and from England. He brought us letters from Mr Everett.

12. I wrote this morning a Note to Count Soltykoff requesting a Courier’s Passport for Captain Stanwood, to embark at Cronstadt for Sweden and going to Gothenburg.— The rest of the day I was almost constantly employed in writing letters to send by him, and by Mr Ingraham, who is to sail in two or three days for Boston— I had no interruptions— Walked before and after dinner. Mrs Adams was very unwell this Evening.

13. I received this morning a large packet from Count Soltykoff, enclosing one for Mr Daschkoff; a Passport for Captain Stanwood, and two Official Notes— Captain Stanwood was here, and is to call Monday Morning for his Passport. Mr Montreal was likewise with me, and informed me that Passports had been refused to the French Ambassador to go to Wilna, and that Mr Prevost would be dispatched by him as a Courier to-morrow morning— I was engaged all the remainder of the day in writing, and was prevented untill near ten at Night, by the weather from walking out— On my return I called at the Chavalier Bezerra’s, and mentioned to him the opportunity for writing— But he dispatches in two or three days a Courier for London, himself.— He and his Lady had been this day down to Cronstadt.— When I came home it was near Midnight— Catherine pass’d the Evening at Madam Colombi’s, and came back sick.— They heard two days ago the death of Baroness Bode, Mrs Colombi’s Mother, at Moscow.

14. I was much engaged in writing dispatches and letters to go by Captain Stanwood and Mr Ingraham, and Official Answers to Count Soltykoff’s Notes— Count Bussche, Mr Harris, and Mr Ingraham and Mr Tilden were with me part of the morning, which absorbed not a little of my Time— After dinner, I rode out with the Ladies Mr Smith to the Catherinen-Hoff procession which we thought would be this day; but which is to be next Sunday— We therefore turned and went to Kammenoi-Ostroff— From whence I walked home— I read the sermons 7 and 8. Vol. 7. of the English Preacher—on Love to Enemies—and on the Excellence of our Saviour’s Doctrine.

15. Mr Montreal, Mr Fisher, and Captain Stanwood were here this morning— I received letters from Archangel and from London, with Newspapers and other Papers— I was much engaged in writing, the whole day; untill the Evening, when I took a long walk— In a letter from Mr Russell at London, I received a Copy of the Embargo Law passed at Washington on the 4th: of April last.

16. Mr Richardson, a person who was here when we first arrived, and who has been here every Summer since, passing for an American but now coming in a vessel under Swedish Colours called upon me this morning, and brought me a packet from Mr George Joy, at London. He also brought a message from Mr Murdoch to Catherine Johnson. He came in seven days from Gothenburg and had news from England to 29. May— No Ministry then formed— I called at the Chevalier Bezerra’s, but he was not at home— I left a letter for Mr Russell to go by his Courier— Mr Ingraham called to take leave, and intends going down to Cronstadt to-morrow morning.— Mr Harris called upon me, and afterwards sent me some English Newspapers, only to 19. May.— I was so much engaged that I missed hearing Charles— Walk in the Summer-Gardens after dinner— On my return home I found Madame Bezerra with the Ladies— She passed the remainder of the Evening here.

17. I received a new letter, respecting the Seamen of the Monticello, who have not received their wages, and Peter Cook the black man, who was in the Angerona, and who has been these three Months in my family—from Mr Sparrow— I sent an Answer by Peter Cook himself. Captain Stanwood called and took my dispatches— His Servant went down in a Boat, with his baggage, and I sent Peter with him— I examined the papers sent me by Mr Hazard from Archangel— Rode out on the Wiburg road, with the Ladies and Charles; and returned by the way of Kammenoi-Ostroff— I walked home— First Accounts this day received of Peace concluded between Russia and Turkey. I was up this Night quite late.

18. Mr Borel paid me a visit this morning, and returned a Volume of American State Papers which he had borrowed some time ago. He is going as Russian Consul to Madeira. While at dinner I received from Count Soltykoff a note with two small packets brought from Stockholm— One was for Mr Harris, and the other for myself; merely an English Newspaper of 21. May, containing Lord Liverpool’s proposals to the Marquis of Wellesley and Mr Canning, to join them as subalterns in the Administration; and their refusal; with all the Correspondence on the Subject— After dinner we rode out to Catherinenhoff, and on returning I called at Mr Harris’s—he was not at home, and I left the Packet for him at his house— Dr: Galloway was here in the Evening to see Charles, who is again unwell; and whose illness alarms me more than I can justify to my Reason, or to my duty of Resignation.

19. The two Sailors of the Monticello came to me again with complaints that they could not obtain their dues, either at Cronstadt, or from Mr Harris here, who had turned them out of his house— While they were here I received a note from Mr Harris concerning them, representing them as refusing a reasonable proposition for arrangement concerning their wages.— They denied the fact, and declared they would gladly accept the proposition— I called on Mr Harris after Breakfast, and proposed to him to take the very words of the proposition in his own Note; and direct Mr Sparrow to make the settlement, as thus proposed, to which he agreed. I accordingly gave them a letter to Sparrow, copying verbatim the terms said in Mr Harris’s Note to have been refused by the men, and requesting him to make the settlement precisely so— With which the men declared they would be satisfied.— I paid a visit also to the French Ambassador, who is yet very unwell— His complaint is now a severe and incessant head-ache which has afflicted him for several weeks— On political affairs I found him soured and exasperated, principally by the refusal to allow him Passports to go to Wilna— I asked him what reason had been assigned— The interruption of the Mails—for it seems the French commanding Officer at Memel or at Königsberg, about a fortnight ago, stopp’d the Post, going from Russia to Germany and the South of Europe, and kept all the letters.— He asked me if I had heard it mentioned as a reason, that Passports had been refused to Prince Kurakin, at Paris— I said I had; and also that Count Lieven at Berlin, had met with the same refusal— He said he knew nothing of the refusal to Count Lieven, but the case of Prince Kurakin was thus— On the departure of the Emperor Napoleon from Paris, Prince Kurakin had said, “I have nothing more to do here,” and had asked for Passports for himself and his family— The Duke de Bassano had furnished him the Passports for all his family, including his pupils (natural children) but had urged him in an amicable manner, and for the sake of avoiding the conclusion which must inevitably be drawn by the Public from his departure, not to insist upon having his own Passport, unless he had orders to that end from his Court— The Prince had accordingly desisted. It was said that after the Emperor Napoleon’s arrival at Dresden, the Prince had again asked for his Passport, and had been again requested to say that it
was by order of his Court, which he had declined— But his Passport was not refused; and the motive for urging him to wait was altogether amicable— Prince Kurakin was exceedingly esteemed at Paris, and not only every right due to his character, but every possible accommodation that he could wish would be afforded him— These facts shew at once the extreme jealousy, suspicion and distrust existing between the parties, and the reluctance they have to begin the War; with the anxiety on each side to throw the first act of aggression upon the other— The Ambassador told me that Count Soltykoff, had been to him in person to inform him of the Peace with Turkey, and to tell him how much satisfaction this Event caused here. “Oh! I congratulated him upon it; and told him that news of Peace was always good news.— And I shall go to the Te Deum— Though I suppose they will look at me, as they did last Year at the Te Deum for General Kutuzoff’s affair at Rustshuk.— I saw them look at me, when I kneeled, as much as to say “Aye! if you pray, it is not for us!”— But after all they have not yet got the Ratifications of this Peace from Constantinople and General Andreossi is there— And certainly by the very last Courier from Constantinople we were in high favour there— The Grand Signor may ratify the Peace and I suppose he will; but if he does it will not be of much importance to Russia, for they have not more than 25000 men on the Danube.— I said I had heard the Ratifications were already received; and that there was not only a Peace but an Alliance Offensive and Defensive— That is all Russian talk, said he— And they have filled poor Count St: Julien’s head with such stuff— He came and told me just such a Story— But you may rely upon it they know nothing of the Conditions of the Treaty— All they have is a Courier sent by Balacheff, the Police-Minister, by the Emperor’s order, with a letter for the Empress, saying that the Peace was signed and the Pruth was to be the boundary— But they are waiting for the Ratifications, and that is the Reason why the Guns have not been fired, and the Te Deum is not to be next Sunday but the Sunday after.— I asked him if he had any news from Sweden— None— But he thought when the Prince Royal had time to grow cool, and to reflect upon things, in the morning, abed, he would find it advisable to change his course a little— He was a man of fiery temper, and had shewn that at Vienna— But he dearly loved his bed, though he was a working man too; and the bed was a very good place for cool reflection— He would at last ask himself, what it would all come to, and what he was staking upon the Event— He did not think it would come to extremities— I mentioned to him the Squadron ready to sail from Cronstadt.—and that it was said they were to land troops in Pomerania, and the Prince Royal was to command the joint expedition. Yes, he said, so he had heard— The Squadron were going to Sweaborg to take in troops there; but he did not believe the Prince-Royal would command them— He had even heard that General Moreau was coming from America to join them, but neither did he believe that— At any rate however, if they were to land in Pomerania there were the Duke of Reggio, Ney and the Duke of Bellune, Marshall Victor, each with thirty thousand men to receive them— And as for that one (the Duke of Bellune) he and the Prince Royal of Sweden “ne sont pas Cousins.”— He asked me about the late changes in the British Administration; I told him what I had collected from the papers to 26. May; he had no accounts so late— I asked him where the Emperor Napoleon was— He did not know— Perhaps at Warsaw— He heard the Russians had concentrated their forces, because they said the Emperor Napoleon always attacks the Centre— There it is; said he— They think, because he has done so before, he will do so again— But with such a Man as that, they will find their calculation fail them— He will do something that they do not expect— He does not copy himself, nor any other— He does something new.— It was near dinner time when I came home— After dinner I rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff with the Ladies, and walked home

20. Mr Harris was with me part of the morning.— I finally examined the papers sent me by Mr Hazard and answered his letter. I received a Statement from Mr Smith, and shall assist him as much as shall be in my power.— After dinner I rode out with the Ladies and Children upon the Wyburg road— At Count Stroganoff’s Garden I quitted the Carriage and walked through the Garden, and down along the Wyburg side of the River to the Bridge crossing to the Petersburg Island, and thence over the Summer Garden Bridge home— A walk of about seven Miles— It took me upwards of two hours. I have adopted this practice of riding out and walking home, for the sake of varying and increasing the quantity of bodily exercise— As I was returning I met the French Ambassador on the Quay— He still complained of severe pain in the head, and had again applied leeches to his temples this morning— He told me that the Grand-Vizir had ratified the Treaty signed by the Turkish Plenipotentiaries; but that the Sultan’s ratification had not yet been received— He said too that he heard the French were erecting a Bridge over from the Curisch-Hoff to Memel.

21. Count Bussche and the Chevalier Bezerra paid me long morning visits— The Count is extremely impatient for the issue of the political Crisis which he thinks lasts intolerably long— He says if it continues three weeks longer he will take a house— He begins to think nothing will be done this Summer— He complained that he was not well paid, and had no provision made for the expences of his Journey home— He said that his Salary was eighty thousand franks a year— But being Westphalian Franks there is a discount upon them of 8 1/2 per Cent, in exchange for French Franks; and he had only twenty thousand franks for the expences of his journey here— And as for an establishment (or outfit) he had never had any thing but promises— Whereas the Chevalier de Bray, who came here about the same time that he did, had received from the king of Bavaria, 30,000 franks for the expences of his journey, 42000 florins for outfit, eight thousand ducats a year Salary, and a present of twenty thousand ducats besides— Of all this De Bray had shewn him the particular account; so that in four years time De Bray had received 160,000 franks more than he had, which was not at-all pleasing to him. He told me also a number of other circumstances respecting his own family and private fortune— The Chevalier Bezerra is still in great distress on account of the decease of his friend Count Linhares, of which he had now received the confirmation— He came to look at my maps of Russia, and has the intention of going to Schlüsselburg, and up the Ladoga-Canal which he thought was the canal uniting the waters of the Caspian with those of the Baltic— I shewed him by the maps and by Coxe, that the Canal of Vishnei Voloshok was a different thing— I lent him the English papers to 26. May, which he returned me in the Evening.— Mr Plummer came and introduced to me Mr Kimball and Mrtwo Americans lately from Moscow; and who arrived last Summer at Archangel— These visits engrossed almost entirely the Morning— After dinner we rode out to the Whitsunday Catherinenhoff procession which was thinly attended, and from which we were obliged to return in the midst of a heavy shower of rain— There had already been one accompanied with thunder in the morning while Mr Bezerra was with me— The weather was so warm this morning that I had been tempted to lay aside my flannel garments; but was obliged to resume the waistcoat in the Evening, and suffered for my imprudent haste— It seems impossible to trust this climate for an hour.— I read the Sermons 7 and 8. Vol. 7. of the English preacher— The first on Anxiety—and the second on Envy— That on Anxiety, is by Atterbury— The text “Take no thought for the morrow” and contained many observations of which I felt the force— My own disposition has in it too much anxiety, and the experience of life has a great tendency to increase that propensity— The precept itself, as Atterbury Remarks is too strongly expressed in the English Translation— A father of a Family, in this world must take thought of To-morrow— Not for what he himself shall eat or drink, or wherewithal he shall be clothed; but for his wife and children— The situations in which I have been placed since the obligation of providing for others has become incumbent upon me, have been almost perpetual temptations, and stimulations to waste the means of provision bestowed upon me by the goodness of that Heavenly father who feeds the fowls of the air, and who clothes the lilies of the field— Had I not a constant, unabating, and unyielding thought for the morrow, my family would long ere this have been destitute, and my children without the means of obtaining a suitable education— With all the thought that I do bestow, and all the precautions that I can take resulting from it, frequent untoward events and unforeseen accidents disconcert all my prudence, and require new sacrifices of feeling, of pleasure, and even of indulgence to the thought for the morrow.— When life must be one uninterrupted struggle against impulses of every kind, to expence beyond income, what but an anxious thought for the morrow, can be adequate to maintain it?— But the guard upon my own disposition which it behoves me to seek, is against allowing this thought for the morrow to run to excess—and to prevent its degenerating into carking Care and distrust of Providence— The Discourse upon Envy, was not very striking to me— I am not conscious of being much afflicted with this vice—and though I cannot deny that I sometimes have felt more of it than was comfortable to myself, I cannot charge myself with ever having indulged it— I read also several Sections of Watts’s Logic, and finished the first Part; on Perception or Ideas— I find in this Book which I studied twenty-seven years ago, and into which I had not since looked, untill this reperusal, much knowledge familiar to my mind, but which I was not conscious of having learnt from it— As I advance in years this experience multiplies upon me— The knowledge remains when the Memory of the Master from whom I learnt it has vanished— If I should ever have the opportunity to examine the progress of my Sons in this part of their Studies, I think I can suggest thoughts to them concerning it, which would have been useful to me, had they been pointed out to me when I first read this Book.— Its method, and its divisions, deserve to be noticed— The five properties essential to perception—clearness—completeness—comprehensiveness, extensiveness, and order are set forth in a variety of forms, and with illustrations which ought to have been better impressed upon my recollection.
The application of these five properties to this Treatise of Logic itself, had escaped my attention heretofore— The remarks upon the definitions of names and things, and upon the distribution of ideas, deserved more reflection than I ever gave to them. It would perhaps be a good exercise for Students in this Art to make them give definitions of various objects, and to discuss their definitions according to the rules in the Book— The practice would I think have a tendency to make them think with precision; a want of which is one of the most copious sources of erroneous opinions, and of misconduct.— Accurate definition is perhaps a more difficult thing than any person would imagine, who never tried the experiment of formally defining.— I had thoughts of going out to see the Sun rise to-morrow; being the Morning of the Summer Solstice; but found myself too unwell.

22. I had one of the Sailors of the Monticello with me again, and still they are deprived of their wages, and baffled in the expectations held out to them of a settlement. I wrote again to Mr Harris on the Subject and received his answer— He afterwards called upon me and promised me either that the settlement should be made, or that he would exercise his authority— I was told too that Marks had contrived to get into the Police, and confined with a Chain at Cronstadt. And Sparrow writes me that Cook came to him intoxicated, and had behaved very much amiss, without otherwise saying how— I spoke to Mr Harris on this subject, and requested that this man might not be abandoned to Marks’s resentment and villainy— He promised me that he should not— This afternoon I walked in the Summer Gardens where the crowd was greater than I had ever seen it before— The number of National Russian dresses among the women was fewer than there were on this occasion either of the former years— On my return home I met Mr J. W. Smith and walked with him. He is going soon to Archangel— The Day was remarkably fine— I still suffer for my yesterday’s change of Garments.

23. Visit this morning from Mr Lewis— I was so unwell that I could not write much—and employed the day in reading the pamphlet Mr Joy sent me from England— The day was foul, with several Thunder showers untill near Sunset— I then walked on the Quays an hour— After returning home I read Dr Winthrop’s two Lectures upon Comets in the Volume sent me by Judge Davis— Dr Galloway was here to day, and I took advice of him.

24. I came in the course of my scripture reading this morning to Psalm 37.— Fret not thyself because of evil-doers &c and was much struck with its excellent and profound morality— The duty of reliance upon the retributive Justice of God, without being staggered either by the transient prosperities of the wicked, or by the afflictions of the good is inculcated with a force of sentiment, and an energy of expression such as I have never met with in any of the profane writers. Plutarch’s Treatise on the delays of divine Justice, and Juvenal’s 13th Satire are not comparable to it—they contain with more diffusion a part of the same doctrine— But this Psalm was written centuries before Homer, and a thousand years before Juvenal and Plutarch— There is not indeed in the Psalm any recurrence to the rewards and punishments of another life, and it leaves the argument entirely open for the sublime improvement of the Christian doctrine— But it is to be observed that one of its promises of blessedness (to the meek; for they shall inherit the Earth) is expressly quoted and repeated by our Saviour in his Sermon on the Mount. (Matt: V.5.) There is so much prosperity to the wicked in this world, and the good, as far as human nature can be called good, are followed by such great and manifold afflictions that some consolotary principle of trust upon divine Justice is necessary to the comfort of existence— I know of none equal to that in this Psalm, with the addition of the Christian faith— Morning Visit from Mr Montréal who told me that the Ambassador had now applied for his Passports to go away, for himself and all his family; but that he would not receive them untill Prince Kurakin shall be on the frontier— Afterwards I had a visit from the Ambassador himself, who told me that Prince Kurakin having for the third time demanded his Passports, they had been sent to him, and that it appeared the Emperor of Russia was determined not to negotiate at-all— That with his last demand for Passports the Prince had sent a Note, offering, on condition of the total evacuation by French troops, of the Prussian Territories, as a preliminary, that the Emperor Alexander would then do, what I, said the Ambassador have been urging and intreating them to do, these twelve-months; that is, send powers to treat about the Duchy of Oldenburg.— And the Duke of Bassano, has sent me an English Newspaper, printed before Prince Kurakin presented his Note, and containing not only the substance of it, but the very words, excepting that it
says that if the French do not evacuate Prussia, the Emperor of Russia will have War— This the Prince’s Note does not say; but otherwise it is in the precise terms of the Article in the English Newspaper. As to the condition, how was it possible to suppose that we could comply with a preliminary dishonourable to ourselves— A proposition which after the Battle of Friedland we never thought of making to Russia on our part— Count St: Julien, and all the Ministers of the Rhenish Confederation, have asked for their Passports also, and have received the same answer— Count Soltikoff had told me before that he was authorized to grant passports for us Ministers; but now he tells me he has dispatched my demand to Wilna— I asked him how this happened after what he had assured me; but he said “Oh! mais a présent c’est autre chose”— So I suppose they keep us as hostages. As to Count St Julien, he used to say to me [“]Ah! Monsieur l’Ambassadeur, you are going away, and I shall have all the women to myself.”— But he too has asked for his Passports— For my own part; as soon as I cross the line at Polangen, I shall turn round; put on my Uniform, and commence soldier again— I am sorry for it; for I should like, to be once for all one thing or another.— Thus it appears that the Rubicon is passed, and before this moment the dogs of War may be loose— The Ambassador asked me to take charge of some papers, relating merely to individuals, and which might even be delivered up if demanded— I told him I would with pleasure take them.— I walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens; and observed from the stand upon the Quay the setting of the sun. Our Italian footman was detected this Evening in thieving.

25. Mr Woodward was with me this morning; and appears to be recovering from the accident he met with some weeks ago— He now talks again of going to Vienna, and some what doubtfully about returning to America, where he ought to have gone the last Autumn.— After dinner I walked in the Summer Gardens and on the Quay. Spent great part of the remainder of the day, writing.

26. Prepared some despatches and letters for America; which Mr Smith gave this Evening to Mr Saltus. After dinner I rode out with the family to Kammenoi-Ostrof and Chrestowsky Islands, and walked home— I have not yet entirely recovered from the rhumatism occasioned by leaving off my flannel waistcoat.

27. I received a letter from Mr John G. Proud at Cronstadt, with one also from Mr Sparrow— Mr Proud states that he is bearer of dispatches for me from Mr Russell at London, but is detained at Cronstadt for want of a Passport which he requests me to obtain for him— I wrote a Note to Count Soltykoff for the purpose, and called upon him to deliver it myself— The Count is authorized to deliver Passports for Courier’s, but no others— So that all Strangers coming into Russia, excepting Mariners coming by Sea, and named on the Ship’s papers are obliged to wait untill Passports are obtained from Wilna— Count Soltykoff hesitated a little as to his authority in this case, for I thought it candid to tell him that although Mr Proud had dispatches for me, he was coming here upon his own private concerns— The Count said that in this last character he could not grant the Passport— But only by considering Mr Proud in the light of a Courier, which upon his own responsibility he would undertake to do, and report the Circumstances to the Emperor.— I asked the Count if he had any news from Wilna— He said he had just received a letter from Count Romanzoff, on a particular subject; and as it was written with his own hand he must have been tolerably well (He has had one or two strokes of Apoplexy at Wilna.) That there was nothing new from there— Butthe Great News, is that which goes from here thither— I suppose you know what “ces Messieurs” have done— I knew he alluded to the demands for Passports from the foreign Ministers, and said I had heard of it— He said it gave him pleasure that in this great reduction of the Corps Diplomatique I was not among the departers— I told him that I was certainly very glad of it myself, and I believed there were among those who were, more than one who would be as reluctant at being included in the number as I should have been— The Count sent me the Passport for Mr Proud, and I left it at Mr Cramer’s to be sent down to him— I called upon Mr Saltus and Mr Slade, whom I saw, and upon Messrs: Delprat, Fisher and Redwood, Lewis and Willing, none of whom were at home— Mr J. W. Smith called on me, and took a couple of letters for Archangel— He is going for that place to-morrow Morning, with Mr Dana— I paid a visit to the French Ambassador, but he was not at home. In the Evening I went with the Ladies, Mr Smith, Charles and Martha to the Theatre, where we saw l’Amant Auteur et Valet, a stupid farce, eminently tedious, and La Belle Arsène, an Opera, which was among the greatest of my delights more than thirty years ago at Passy, and which I think I have not seen since— Though now more indifferently performed than I ever saw it before, the Music charmed me as much as ever, and there was scarcely a Note but sounded as familiarly to my ear as if I had heard it within a week— The fashion of this Music has passed away, but it is still delightful to me. I walked home— Heavy Showers of Rain at intervals, the whole day and Evening.

28. Mr: Rayneval the Secretary of the French Embassy called upon me this morning to take leave— He goes this Night as a Courier, with his wife; and is not unconcerned, as to the safety of his passage out of the Country— He told me that a Courier had arrived last Night from Wilna in 47 hours, with the news that hostilities had commenced—that the French had passed the Niemen or Memel River at Kovno, which we found upon the great Russian Map— On their passage the Russian troops there had retired. The two Empresses it was expected he said would return to the City this Evening; and would reside here— It was said to be customary in time of War—or at least in Wars “un peu interressantes”— They have not been more than a week or ten days in the Country— I received the letter from Mr Russell, brought by Mr Proud— The French Ambassador paid us a visit in the Evening— He is yet waiting for his Passports from Wilna— He thinks the passage of the River at Kovno a very formidable manoeuvre, and says that it cuts off four divisions from the Russian line— Now, he says they are quite astonished at it here, because they expected to be attacked on the side of Grodno; and now they begin to be sorry that Passports were refused him for going to Wilna— I rode out with the Ladies and Children to Kammenoi-ostrof, and walked home— Read Sermons 9. and 10. Vol. 7. of the English Preacher— On the folly of imitating popular and fashionable Vices, and on Justice— The precept “thou shalt not follow a Multitude to do evil,[”] is one of the most difficult to be practised, of all the Virtues prescribed in the Bible— Few of us are sensible how much we yield to the prevailing Spirit of others; nor is it always perfectly clear when compliance and when resistance is the duty— A just and sober judgment, a pure intention, and an ardent desire to do right are the qualities for which it becomes us to offer unceasing prayers to Heaven— The Discourse on Justice is a Common Place— It says that the Roman Emperor Alexander Severus, was said to have erected a Temple to Christ, for the Precept of doing to others whatsoever we would that they should do unto us— I know not where this anecdote was found— There is a discussion of the principle in a paper of the Rambler, better than this Sermon.

29. Morning Visits from Mr Delprat and Mr Ogden, and from Mr E. Plummer, and Mr Proud who brought a letter of introduction from Mr Russell— Mr Fisher also called upon me respecting a vessel arrived from Lisbon, which at the Custom-house is said not to be admissible— I called at the Chevalier Bezerra’s to converse with him on the subject; but he was not at home— Walked in the Summer Gardens; on my return home found Mr Harris, who mentioned the Report that the French troops had invaded the Russian Territory in two Columns, and that the Emperor Alexander had written to Count Soltykoff declaring that he never would make Peace while there should be a Frenchman upon Russian Ground— I received also from Mr Hazard at Archangel a letter with some Complaints upon which he requests advice— Visit also this morning from Mr Raimbert; who told me that the Ambassador had received his Passports, but he was misinformed.

30. The St: Petersburg Gazette of this morning contains the Emperor’s Rescript to Count Nicholas Soltykoff the President of the Imperial Council, announcing the invasion of the Russian Territories by the French; and his Resolution never to make Peace, so long as an enemy remains in arms upon his territory— Mr Fisher came to me again with his Custom House Clerk; concerning the vessel from Lisbon, which is refused at the Custom-House to be admitted— I sent to enquire if Mr Bezerra was at home that I might call upon him— He sent me for answer that he would himself call upon me; which he did— I mentioned to him the detention of this ship for entering from Lisbon, notwithstanding the renewal of the Treaty lately concluded with him— He said he would immediately go to the Minister of Commerce Mr Gourieff, and if he could not see him would write to him, and if necessary to Count Soltykoff— The vessel is loaded with fruit, which has been very long on its passage, and is daily perishing— Mr Bezerra wrote me afterwards that he had called on Mr Gourieff, and seen not him but his Son, who said there could be no difficulty in the case, and that the order for its admission should be immediately sent— I had a visit from Count Frohberg the Wurtemberg Minister, who told me that he had not yet received his Passports, and did not how it was intended they should go— Some said they were to be sent off in a Frigate, and landed at Memel or Dantzig. Others that they were to be directed to take their course roundabout to the Turkish and Austrian frontier— It was wished that they might not have the opportunity to observe the military State of the Country, as it is supposed they would by passing through the very theatre of the War— The Count asked me to take charge of a small packet of Papers, which I promised him I would do— I paid a visit
to the Ambassador, who is very anxious to be gone— Rayneval went off yesterday as a Courier; with his wife. The Count still thinks that the passage at Kovno was a surprize upon the Russians, and a “Superbe debut.”— We had Messrs: Harris and his nephew, Boit, Calhoun, Delprat, Fisher, Hall, Kimball, Lewis, Ogden, Redwood, Saltus, Slade, Tilden, Wallace to dine with us— Mr Baylies and Mr Willing had been invited, but sent excuses— I walked late in the Evening.

Day. Since the days have been at the period of their greatest length, and while there is no Night, I have found it impracticable to keep even so much regularity in the distribution of my time as I did in the Winter— There has hitherto been scarcely any warm, and very little fair weather— I have no temptation to walk in the morning, and seldom go out untill after dinner— I then usually ride out with my family seven or eight miles, and walk five or six of them home— This occupies the Evening untill past ten at Night; and an hour or two insensibly slips away, in amusements with Charles, and conversation. Sometimes, with an occasional visitor— I rise proportionably late from seven to nine in the Morning— Most commonly about eight— As for the rest my occupations continue the same— I still hear Charles read in the first Volume of Dufief’s Grammar, and in Berquin— But he has been part of this Month so unwell that his lessons have suffered from it— He has read much less than last Month, and has made very little if any progress— His English pronunciation especially seems rather to fail than to improve in correctness— He speaks French always; even when we speak in English to him.
